messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: Asteroids are big rocks in space. Some asteroids can be dangerous. They are called 'Potentially Hazardous Asteroids' (PHAs). This means they fly very close to Earth. They pass less than 7.5 million kilometres away. NASA made a map of 1,400 PHAs. But we are safe. None of them are a danger for the next 100 years. NASA has technology to watch these rocks. So, NASA can say if a rock is going to hit Earth. If an asteroid is a danger, we have a plan. We can use two ways to protect ourselves.

metadata.feedback_text: FAILED. The word 'protect' is B1 level. This violates the strict A2 vocabulary rule. The goal is to use vocabulary the learner already possesses, not to teach new words. The sentence structure and factual accuracy are correct, but the use of a single B1 word results in an immediate failure. An A2 alternative like 'keep us safe' was required.
